Kent Beck wrote:
> @Test takes two optional parameters. A test annotated @Test(timeout=100)
> will fail if the test takes longer than 100 milliseconds to complete. A test
> annotated @Test(expected=NullPointerException.class) will fail if a
> NullPointerException is not thrown and succeed if a NullPointerException is
> thrown.

Kent,

These are both examples of decorators (as I'm sure you know).

Rather than simply hard-code in just two decorators, is there any chance 
you could provide a generic parameter for defining decorators on a per test 
method (and class) basis?

e.g.
@TestSuite(decorator=foo.bar.WibbleDecorator.class)
public class SomeTest {

   @Test(decorator=foo.bar.XyzzyDecorator.class)
   public void testWhatever() {
     ...
   }
}


The decorator support in JUnit is a very powerful technique, and one that's 
been underutilised by many JUnit extensions. One reason is that decorating 
tests isn't that easy - while suite-level decorators aren't hard, 
testcase-level decorators require populating the suite by hand. :( 
Annotation-based decorator declaration would go a long way to solving that.

I'd also like to see an annotation-based version of the suite() method, 
thus keeping in the trend of providing alternatives to the existing 
reflection based techniques.

Robert.
